author: Rob Polansky
title: ‘Not all patients are humans’: 14 puppies rescued from rollover vehicle crash
text: WOODSTOCK, CT ( WFSB /Gray News) - Fourteen puppies were rescued from a rollover crash that closed a road in Woodstock, Connecticut Thursday morning. Several fire agencies responded to Senexet Road between Laurel and Bull Hill roads for a single-vehicle rollover accident involving wires down. Firefighters found a pole that had snapped, with wires down, and called Eversource CT to disable the power. Power was out in the area while the electricians worked. Officials say minor injuries were originally reported, but no one ended up being hurt. First responders also rescued and provided care for 14 puppies at the scene. the Muddy Brook Fire Department shared photos on Facebook of firefighters interacting with the puppies. The Necogg Humane Society and a doctor from Peake Brook Veterinary Center responded to the scene to provide veterinary care and shelter to the animals, firefighters said. Some puppies will be taken to a veterinary office for further care. Drivers were warned to expect a “long duration road closure.” Copyright 2024 WFSB via Gray Media Group, Inc. All rights reserved.

author: mdzol.com
title: Se retoman las actividades en el Parque Nacional Lanín luego de los incendios
text:
Se retoman las actividades en el Parque Nacional Lanín luego de los incendios
Luego de varias semanas de combate, las precipitaciones ayudaron a contener el fuego, que afectó una superficie de 24.100 hectáreas, y ciertas actividades turisticas podrán reactivarse.
A partir de este martes, luego de los incontrolables incendios forestales que sufrió Valle Magdalena, el volcán Lanín volverá a quedar habilitado para los ascensos y otras actividades de montaña, según anunciaron las autoridades.
Desde mediados de febrero, Neuquén se empeñó en combatir el fuego, que afectó una superficie de 24.100 hectáreas en la región de Valle Magdalena. Sin embargo, la intendencia del Parque Nacional Lanín confirmó ayer a través de sus redes sociales que las condiciones han mejorado lo suficiente para permitir la reactivación de las actividades turísticas.
De acuerdo al posteo, el horario para el desarrollo de las actividades dentro del área es de 08 a 20 horas. También, para el ascenso al volcan, se debe realizar el registro en la página web del parque y una declaración jurada en el Centro de Informes de Rio Turbio de 08:00 a las 14hs. El Camping Tromen, por su parte, también retoma sus actividades habituales.
No obstante, el uso del Lago Tromen porque, según las autoridades "los medios aéreos del incendio siguen operando en el lugar". Por otro lado, solicitaron a todos los visitantes "no detenerse en ningún tramo de la ruta provincial y transitar con extrema precaución".
Por su parte, según los reportes del área técnica de Incendio, Comunicación y Emergencia, las precipitaciones que se registraron este fin de semana contribuyeron significativamente a la contención del fuego. Se registraron acumulaciones de lluvia de 41.66 mm en Tromen, 32.5 mm en Quillén y 61.7 mm en Paimún, además de nevadas en las zonas de alta montaña.

author: @simonthejourno
title: Heatwave hits Australia with high fire danger warning
text:
Heatwave conditions were creeping back up from the south on Friday afternoon, as the mercury was set to rise well above the 30-degree marker over the weekend.
Tops of a scorching 39 degrees were expected on Sunday as a strong high-pressure system displaces the status quo in the Tasman.
The blistering heat had firefighters on alert across the country on Friday, as the hot, dry weather made it difficult to contain existing blazes.
The fire danger warning was expected to increase from Moderate on Friday to High over the weekend as the heat intensified. The state's Rural Fire Service says at a High danger rating, residents need to be ready to act in case of an emergency.
The chance of a shower over Newcastle, Maitland and Gosford on Friday afternoon lingered even as the cloud cover broke up and temperatures mingled in the high 20s and low 30s.
A chance of fog and a possible thunderstorm in some parts in the early morning on Saturday looked set to burn off to a balmy 30-degree day.
An early grey start in Newcastle yielded to a warm and blustery afternoon that left conditions lumpy and poor in the surf as holiday beachgoers headed to the sand to cool off.
The surf conditions looked more optimistic into next week as models show a rapidly developing low from below Tasmania to the south-east that should result in a decent south swell up the Tasman to add to the local short-period swell.
"Bigger surf than recently is likely, although winds could be tricky with lots of onshore flow indicated," forecasters for Surfline say.
With AAP

author: Hellenicshippingnews
title: Prices inch higher in Vietnam amid sluggish trade, low supplies
text:
Coffee prices in Vietnam inched higher, with trading activities coming to a haltdue to a prolonged shortage of robusta beans, while prices in Indonesia fell this week amid high London prices, traders said on Thursday.
Farmers in the Central Highlands, Vietnam’s largest coffee-growing area, were selling beans COFVN-DAK for 127,000-127,700 dong ($5.00-$5.02) per kg, up from 120,000-122,000 dong a week ago.
“Domestic prices were up following a surge in global market due to lower shipments from Vietnam,” a trader based in the coffee belt said.
“Activity is very tepid now and will remain this sluggish until at least early November. Only those who have to fulfil their contracts will buy at this current sky high price.”
The price of robusta beans LRCc2 has risen 63% this year, peaking on Tuesday at $4,667 a metric ton on the London-based ICE Futures Europe market.
Vietnam’s coffee exports in the first half of this year were 893,820 tons, down 11.4% from a year earlier, customs data showed. Vietnam exported 70,202 tons of coffee in June, a decrease of 11.5% from the previous month.
Another trader based in the same area said current weather condition was favourable for the coffee cherries to grow.
Traders offered 5% black and broken-grade 2 robusta COFVN-G25-SAI at a premium of $600 per ton to the September contract.
In Indonesia, Sumatra robusta beans were offered at $750 premium per ton to the August contract, $200 less than last week, a trader said.
Another trader quoted $770 premium per ton to September contract, down from $950 premium a week ago, adding prices were quite volatile.
Source: Reuters (Reporting by Phuong Nguyen and Mas Alina Arifin; Editing by Rashmi Aich)

author: EdiCase
title: 6 sinais que podem ajudar no diagnóstico do autismo em crianças
text:
O diagnóstico do Transtorno do Espectro Autista (TEA) em crianças é um processo delicado que demanda uma avaliação minuciosa realizada por profissionais de saúde especializados. No entanto, muitas vezes, alguns sinais podem surgir nos primeiros anos de vida. Saber identificá-los pode ajudar no diagnóstico precoce, o que melhora a qualidade de vida dos pequenos.
De acordo com um relatório da Rede de Monitoramento de Autismo e Deficiências do Desenvolvimento do CDC, publicado em março de 2023, estima-se que 1 em cada 36 crianças são diagnosticadas com Transtorno do Espectro Autista.
Pensando na importância do tema, a Dra Kelly Oliveira, pediatra especialista em amamentação e sono, pós graduanda em autismo, destaca 6 sinais de atenção para pais e mães observarem em suas crianças durante o seu crescimento. Confira!
1. Andar na ponta dos pés
Crianças com
autismo
podem andar nas pontas dos pés como uma maneira de estimular seus sentidos ou se acalmar. Além disso, esse comportamento também pode estar relacionado a dificuldades motoras ou de equilíbrio, e hipersensibilidade da criança, sendo uma forma de reduzir o estímulo tátil com o chão.
2. Movimentos repetitivos
As estereotipias são movimentos repetitivos que ajudam no diagnóstico de autismo. Elas podem envolver questões motoras mais evidentes, como balançar as mãos e os braços, agitar os dedos, balançar de um lado para o outro e andar pra lá e pra cá repetidamente. Também pode ocorrer a repetição de sons. Normalmente, isso acontece quando a criança recebe muitos estímulos ao mesmo tempo.
3. Comportamentos sensoriais incomuns
Embora seja comum se incomodar com um som demasiadamente alto, as crianças autistas podem apresentar uma aversão particularmente forte a esses ruídos. Elas podem reagir fazendo caretas, sinais de dor ou colocando as mãos nos ouvidos. Além disso, podem apresentar a mesma aversão ao contato físico, não gostando do toque das pessoas e irritando-se ao receber carinhos e abraços.
4. Bebês que não fazem jogo de imitação e evitam contato visual
Os bebês desde muito cedo aprendem a fazer contato visual com seus pais e, logo em seguida, começam a imitar as reações, emoções, atitudes e
comportamentos
dos seus cuidadores. Crianças autistas possuem dificuldade em reconhecer emoções e expressões faciais, por isso, podem demonstrar pouca ou nenhuma emoção diante das reações das pessoas ao seu redor. Também é comum que crianças autistas não olhem quando são chamadas pelo nome ou não sustentem o olhar, evitando o contato visual.
5. Falta de interesse para interagir com o mundo ao seu redor
Crianças com TEA podem parecer desatentas e responder de maneiras diferentes aos estímulos externos. Por exemplo, quando alguém tenta chamar a atenção e elas não viram a cabeça para a direção da pessoa. Não apontar na direção de objetos e não demonstrar curiosidade também podem ser pontos de atenção.
6. Atraso na fala
Crianças com TEA podem apresentar dificuldades para se comunicar e não apresentar o nível de fala esperado para a idade. Existem casos de crianças com TEA que balbuciam e choramingam durante os primeiros anos de vida, mas logo depois, param de se comunicar. Este deve ser um dos principais pontos de atenção, pois a intervenção precoce é crucial para ajudar
crianças autistas
a desenvolverem a comunicação.
O diagnóstico pode demorar a se confirmar
O diagnóstico de autismo pode demorar vários meses para ser confirmado depois que os responsáveis pela criança identificam os primeiros sinais. Por isso, é de extrema importância que, caso exista qualquer suspeita, os pais ou cuidadores conversem com o pediatra ou neuropediatra e iniciem o tratamento o quanto antes. O trabalho de uma equipe médica multidisciplinar, que inclui pediatras, fisioterapeutas, fonoaudiólogos e psicólogos, é fundamental para o desenvolvimento e o bem-estar da criança.
Por Isabel Bergami

author: Derek Strickland
title: CD Projekt confident it can self-fund all new game projects
text: CD Projekt Group is confident it can self-fund all 5 of its new video game projects, including a new Witcher trilogy. Following 2015's best-selling The Witcher 3, and 2020's record-breaking Cyberpunk 2077, CD Projekt has been able to consistently generated high sales revenues from its games. During Cyberpunk's controversial launch, the company sold 13 million copies and made $541 million in sales--almost 5x the budget of the game. Alongside a multi-faceted business model that includes a fully-fledged software distribution storefront, the sci-fi shooter's performance helped CD Projekt amass a significant asset pile to fund future games and growth. Cyberpunk 2077 has seen various price fluctuations and re-releases, including steep discounts post-launch, a game-of-the-year-style re-release for next-gen consoles, and the standalone launch of the Phantom Liberty expansion. The company also re-released The Witcher 3 for PS5 and Xbox Series X/S. This cyclical product slate is often used in the industry, and it's a key part of CD Projekt's business model. Armed with years of successful game sales across both retail and digital channels, CD Projekt management believes that there's plenty of funds for its large multi-year project slate. This plan includes video games and transmedia. In a recent interview with Polish newspaper [Parkiet](https://www-parkiet-com.translate.goog/technologie/art39620191-adam-kicinski-ceo-cd-projektu-jestesmy-znow-na-ringu-w-pelni-sil?_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=wapp&_x_tr_sl=auto&_x_tr_tl=en&utm_source=pocket_reader), CD Projekt CEO Adam Kicinski talks about the firm's financial guardrails that help ensure long-term success and continued investment: "There have been various difficult situations in the history of CD Projekt so far. We have drawn conclusions from them and have been operating on the principle of having large buffers for years. We feel safe with the cash we have. "Our strategy is well calculated. We believe that we will implement it from start to finish using our own funds. We do not need to reach for additional sources of financing." The news comes shortly after Kicisnki said that CD Projekt has [no intention of being acquired by a larger company](https://www.tweaktown.com/news/95178/cd-projekt-still-not-interested-in-being-acquired-we-value-our-independence/index.html). As per a [Q3 2023 results filing](https://www.cdprojekt.com/en/investors/regulatory-announcements/consolidated-report-for-q3-2023/) made last month, the company currently has over $600 million in assets.

author: @adndotcom
title: Up to the challenge: UAA's new women's basketball coach embraces the pressure of replacing a legend
text:
New University of Alaska Anchorage women’s basketball head coach Matt Thune has massive shoes to fill.
He is the successor to the legendary Ryan McCarthy, who established the Seawolves as one of the top NCAA Division II teams during his 13 years at the helm. McCarthy departed last month to become the head coach at the Division I level with Fresno State.
“I have a lot of respect for Ryan and what he’s done here,” Thune said. “It’s hard to sustain winning anywhere. Him and I spent a few hours the other day talking (about) everything UAA and he was giving me some help.”
Thune is coming to coach at the Division II level after spending last year as an assistant at Division I Seattle University. With McCarthy moving up to Division I, the two gave each other tips on coaching and recruiting.
[‘Change is inevitable’: Departing UAA women’s basketball coach and players reflect on his history and impact]
Whether Thune was taking over for one of the best programs in the nation or tasked with turning around one that had been downtrodden, pressure was inevitable. But he wouldn’t let it get to him either way.
“No matter what situation you’re in, there’s pressure to win,” he said. “It’s more just excitement about the school (and) the facilities we have here. It’s a great opportunity, and when players come here to see it, the kids I’m recruiting right now are super hype.”
Four former Seawolves who were key to last year’s success are following McCarthy to Fresno State to become Bulldogs. The list includes standout guard Emilia Long, who led the team in assists and steals and was the second-leading scorer, as well as forward Ashlyn Rean, who finished second in rebounds and fourth in scoring.
Former Colony High School standout Indiya Clarke, who was initially going to transfer to UAA, will also be joining McCarthy in Fresno.
The only holdover who played a wealth of meaningful minutes for the team last year is guard Elaina Mack of King Cove, so in some ways, Thune feels like they’re starting fresh.
“We still have incoming freshmen from Alaska. We’re going to mix a group of transfers and stuff like that,” he said. “His style of basketball, there’s not really going to be that learning curve or all those types of dynamics because nobody on the team was really here for it. … You can come in and put your system in and recruit to the way you like to play and get after it.”
Dispelling misconceptions
Thune believes his wealth of experience from coaching over a decade at the Division I level is transferable.
“There’s good basketball everywhere, so I don’t like to get into the comparison game both ways because I think at Division I level, there tends to be a general disrespect on what goes on at Division II, which I don’t agree with,” he said.
Thune, who has made multiple coaching stops in the past five years, made a habit of following basketball at all levels and has close friends who coach at Division II and III schools.
“If you see good basketball, you know where it’s at,” he said. “There are kids that I’ve coached at previous institutions that are in this league so I’ve been watching them the last few years and it’s going to be fun and a challenge. If it wasn’t, it wouldn’t be too enjoyable. You want something that’s hard. If it’s easy, it gets boring.”
Upholding tradition and strong community presence
McCarthy, who grew up in Alaska, was a pillar in the Anchorage basketball community on and off the court. A big staple of every program Thune has been a part of was being involved with the community, and he plans to continue doing that in his new position.
“It’s important to get out into the community with open arms and meet everybody that wants to show you support,” he said. “The women’s basketball team having the support of the community is a huge thing because for our kids to be able to see fans in the stands for all the work they put in is awesome.”
Thune is excited to meet new people and learn all he can about the state, Anchorage and the university that he’ll be calling home for the foreseeable future.
“I’ve been doing that in the short time that I’ve been here so far for about a week,” he said. “Every day I’m meeting new people and getting phone calls.”
The next step is assembling a staff that can help make the vision he has for the program come to fruition.
“I think we should hit the ground running,” Thune said.
A big part of his responsibility as the next Seawolves head coach is helping facilitate the Great Alaska Shootout by getting quality teams interested in making the trek north for the tournament.
“When I was on my way up here, I was on the phone with 50 to 100 coaches, so there’s interest,” Thune said. “As long as we can facilitate the tournament, there’s going to be people that want to come up here.”
He began his coaching career as an assistant at the University of Louisville under head coach Jeff Walz, who wants to bring the Cardinals to the Shootout in the next year or two.
“I got to dive in and really learn what that experience is about and what that tournament looks like,” Thune said. “I kind of know it from afar.”
There are also former Alaska prep stars currently playing at Division I and II colleges who fans of the program and families of those players would like to see come up for a game, even if it isn’t for the Shootout.
One of the most notable of the bunch is University of Washington guard Sayvia Sellers, who starred at Anchorage Christian School and is coming off a breakout sophomore campaign for the Huskies. There’s a strong chance that she could grace the hardwood at the Alaska Airlines Center for the first time since leading the Lions to a fourth straight state title as a senior in 2023.
“Her coaches are open to it right now, so we just got to get them to sign on a line,” Thune said.
Ideal family dynamics
Thune is bringing his wife, Kaitlin, and two children — son Vance and daughter Chandler — along with him to embark on this next chapter of his career and their lives.
“We’re accustomed to moving around the country,” Thune said. “I’ve done it multiple times. I’ve moved from the Midwest out West, from out West to Boston, and we made our way back West (to Seattle). We’re kind of troopers.”
Thune said his wife has been “all on board” with every move their young family has had to make as a result of his career. Given her background working in college athletics, she understands what the lifestyle entails, he says.
She also enjoys the outdoors and is ecstatic about the opportunity to live in Alaska.
“We met while we were in Utah and this part of the country has just kind of captivated us,” Thune said.
Their children will also be staples at practices and other sporting events on campus, not just basketball.
“They can’t wait to get up here,” Thune said. “We were able to get a house situated, so it’s really just about getting up here and getting comfortable, getting acquainted with people in the community, and my wife likes to be around the team as well.”
The Thunes are already beginning to plan family excursions around the state, including popular tourist attractions such as museums in Anchorage and the Alaska SeaLife Center in Seward.
“We have a laundry list going, and we’ll probably try to attack it until the season starts,” he said.
